member.summary: The and members are valid.

summary.para: Display a balloon notification. The , , , and members are valid. Note that is valid only in Windows 2000 and Windows XP.
To display the balloon notification, specify and provide text in .
To remove a balloon notification, specify and provide an empty string through .
To add a notification area icon without displaying a notification, do not set the flag.
Windows 7 and later: The guidItem is valid.
Windows Vista and earlier: Reserved.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.NotifyIconFlags.RealTime
member.summary: Windows Vista and later. If the balloon notification cannot be displayed immediately, discard it. Use this flag for notifications that represent real-time information which would be meaningless or misleading if displayed at a later time. For example, a message that states "Your telephone is ringing." is meaningful only when combined with the flag.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.NotifyIconFlags.ShowTip
member.summary: Windows Vista and later. Use the standard tooltip. Normally, when is set to , the standard tooltip is suppressed and can be replaced by the application-drawn, pop-up UI. If the application wants to show the standard tooltip with , it can specify to indicate the standard tooltip should still be shown.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.NotifyIconStates.Hidden
member.summary: The icon is hidden.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.NotifyIconStates.SharedIcon
member.summary: The icon resource is shared between multiple icons.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.NotifyIconModification.Add
member.summary: Adds an icon to the status area. The icon is given an identifier in the structure pointed to by lpdataâ€”either through its uID or guidItem member. This identifier is used in subsequent calls to to perform later actions on the icon.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.NotifyIconModification.Modify
member.summary: Modifies an icon in the status area. structure pointed to by lpdata uses the ID originally assigned to the icon when it was added to the notification area () to identify the icon to be modified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.NotifyIconModification.Delete
member.summary: Deletes an icon from the status area. structure pointed to by lpdata uses the ID originally assigned to the icon when it was added to the notification area () to identify the icon to be deleted.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.NotifyIconModification.SetFocus
member.summary: Shell32.dll version 5.0 and later only. Returns focus to the taskbar notification area. Notification area icons should use this message when they have completed their UI operation. For example, if the icon displays a shortcut menu, but the user presses ESC to cancel it, use to return focus to the notification area.

summary.para: Shell32.dll version 5.0 and later only. Instructs the notification area to behave according to the version number specified in the member of the structure pointed to by lpdata. The version number specifies which members are recognized.
must be called every time a notification area icon is added ()>. It does not need to be called with . The version setting is not persisted once a user logs off.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.EmptyRecycleBinFlags.NoProgressUI
member.summary: No dialog box indicating the progress will be displayed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.EmptyRecycleBinFlags.NoSound

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetPropertyStoreOptions
member.summary: Indicate flags that modify the property store object retrieved by methods that create a property store, such as IShellItem2::GetPropertyStore or IPropertyStoreFactory::GetPropertyStore.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetPropertyStoreOptions.Default
member.summary: Meaning to a calling process: Return a read-only property store that contains all properties. Slow items (offline files) are not opened. Combination with other flags: Can be overridden by other flags.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetPropertyStoreOptions.HandlePropertiesOnly
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Include only properties directly from the property handler, which opens the file on the disk, network, or device. Meaning to a file folder: Only include properties directly from the handler.
Meaning to other folders: When delegating to a file folder, pass this flag on to the file folder; do not do any multiplexing (MUX). When not delegating to a file folder, ignore this flag instead of returning a failure code.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with GPS_TEMPORARY, GPS_FASTPROPERTIESONLY, or GPS_BESTEFFORT.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetPropertyStoreOptions.ReadWrite
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Can write properties to the item. Note: The store may contain fewer properties than a read-only store.
Meaning to a file folder: ReadWrite.
Meaning to other folders: ReadWrite. Note: When using default MUX, return a single unmultiplexed store because the default MUX does not support ReadWrite.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with GPS_TEMPORARY, GPS_FASTPROPERTIESONLY, GPS_BESTEFFORT, or GPS_DELAYCREATION. Implies GPS_HANDLERPROPERTIESONLY.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetPropertyStoreOptions.Temporary
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Provides a writable store, with no initial properties, that exists for the lifetime of the Shell item instance; basically, a property bag attached to the item instance.
Meaning to a file folder: Not applicable. Handled by the Shell item.
Meaning to other folders: Not applicable. Handled by the Shell item.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with any other flag. Implies GPS_READWRITE

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetPropertyStoreOptions.FastPropertiesOnly
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Provides a store that does not involve reading from the disk or network. Note: Some values may be different, or missing, compared to a store without this flag.
Meaning to a file folder: Include the "innate" and "fallback" stores only. Do not load the handler.
Meaning to other folders: Include only properties that are available in memory or can be computed very quickly (no properties from disk, network, or peripheral IO devices). This is normally only data sources from the IDLIST. When delegating to other folders, pass this flag on to them.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with GPS_TEMPORARY, GPS_READWRITE, GPS_HANDLERPROPERTIESONLY, or GPS_DELAYCREATION.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetPropertyStoreOptions.OpensLowItem
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Open a slow item (offline file) if necessary. Meaning to a file folder: Retrieve a file from offline storage, if necessary. Note: Without this flag, the handler is not created for offline files.
Meaning to other folders: Do not return any properties that are very slow.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with GPS_TEMPORARY or GPS_FASTPROPERTIESONLY.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetPropertyStoreOptions.DelayCreation
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Delay memory-intensive operations, such as file access, until a property is requested that requires such access.
Meaning to a file folder: Do not create the handler until needed; for example, either GetCount/GetAt or GetValue, where the innate store does not satisfy the request. Note: GetValue might fail due to file access problems.
Meaning to other folders: If the folder has memory-intensive properties, such as delegating to a file folder or network access, it can optimize performance by supporting IDelayedPropertyStoreFactory and splitting up its properties into a fast and a slow store. It can then use delayed MUX to recombine them.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with GPS_TEMPORARY or GPS_READWRITE

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetPropertyStoreOptions.BestEffort
member.summary:
Meaning to a calling process: Succeed at getting the store, even if some properties are not returned. Note: Some values may be different, or missing, compared to a store without this flag.
Meaning to a file folder: Succeed and return a store, even if the handler or innate store has an error during creation. Only fail if substores fail.
Meaning to other folders: Succeed on getting the store, even if some properties are not returned.
Combination with other flags: Cannot be combined with GPS_TEMPORARY, GPS_READWRITE, or GPS_HANDLERPROPERTIESONLY.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetPropertyStoreOptions.MaskValid
member.summary: Mask for valid GETPROPERTYSTOREFLAGS values.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes
member.summary: Provides attributes for files and directories.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.ReadOnly
member.summary: The file is read-only. is supported on Windows, Linux, and macOS. On Linux and macOS, changing the flag is a permissions operation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Hidden
member.summary: The file is hidden, and thus is not included in an ordinary directory listing. is supported on Windows, Linux, and macOS.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.System
member.summary: The file is a system file. That is, the file is part of the operating system or is used exclusively by the operating system.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Directory
member.summary: The file is a directory. is supported on Windows, Linux, and macOS.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Archive
member.summary: This file is marked to be included in incremental backup operation. Windows sets this attribute whenever the file is modified, and backup software should clear it when processing the file during incremental backup.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Device
member.summary: Reserved for future use.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Normal
member.summary: The file is a standard file that has no special attributes. This attribute is valid only if it is used alone. is supported on Windows, Linux, and macOS.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Temporary
member.summary: The file is temporary. A temporary file contains data that is needed while an application is executing but is not needed after the application is finished. File systems try to keep all the data in memory for quicker access rather than flushing the data back to mass storage. A temporary file should be deleted by the application as soon as it is no longer needed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.SparseFile
member.summary: The file is a sparse file. Sparse files are typically large files whose data consists of mostly zeros.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.ReparsePoint
member.summary: The file contains a reparse point, which is a block of user-defined data associated with a file or a directory. is supported on Windows, Linux, and macOS.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Compressed
member.summary: The file is compressed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Offline
member.summary: The file is offline. The data of the file is not immediately available.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.NotContentIndexed
member.summary: The file will not be indexed by the operating system's content indexing service.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Encrypted
member.summary: The file or directory is encrypted. For a file, this means that all data in the file is encrypted. For a directory, this means that encryption is the default for newly created files and directories.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.IntegrityStream
member.summary: The file or directory includes data integrity support. When this value is applied to a file, all data streams in the file have integrity support. When this value is applied to a directory, all new files and subdirectories within that directory, by default, include integrity support.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.Virtual
member.summary: This value is reserved for system use.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.NoScrubData
member.summary: The file or directory is excluded from the data integrity scan. When this value is applied to a directory, by default, all new files and subdirectories within that directory are excluded from data integrity.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.RecallOnOpen
member.summary: This attribute only appears in directory enumeration classes (FILE_DIRECTORY_INFORMATION, FILE_BOTH_DIR_INFORMATION, etc.). When this attribute is set, it means that the file or directory has no physical representation on the local system; the item is virtual. Opening the item will be more expensive than normal, e.g. it will cause at least some of it to be fetched from a remote store.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.EA
member.summary: Same as

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes.RecallOnDataAccess
member.summary: When this attribute is set, it means that the file or directory is not fully present locally. For a file that means that not all of its data is on local storage (e.g. it may be sparse with some data still in remote storage). For a directory it means that some of the directory contents are being virtualized from another location. Reading the file / enumerating the directory will be more expensive than normal, e.g. it will cause at least some of the file/directory content to be fetched from a remote store. Only kernel-mode callers can set this bit.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.CopyFileFlags
member.summary: Flags that specify how the file is to be copied.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.CopyFileFlags.FailIfExists
member.summary: The copy operation fails immediately if the target file already exists.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.CopyFileFlags.Restartable
member.summary: Progress of the copy is tracked in the target file in case the copy fails. The failed copy can be restarted at a later time by specifying the same values for lpExistingFileName and lpNewFileName as those used in the call that failed. This can significantly slow down the copy operation as the new file may be flushed multiple times during the copy operation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.CopyFileFlags.OpenSourceForWrite
member.summary: The file is copied and the original file is opened for write access.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.CopyFileFlags.AllowDecryptedDestination
member.summary: An attempt to copy an encrypted file will succeed even if the destination copy cannot be encrypted.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.CopyFileFlags.CopySymLink
member.summary:
If the source file is a symbolic link, the destination file is also a symbolic link pointing to the same file that the source symbolic link is pointing to.
Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.CopyFileFlags.NoBuffering
member.summary:
The copy operation is performed using unbuffered I/O, bypassing system I/O cache resources. Recommended for very large file transfers.
Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.MoveFileFlags
member.summary: Flags that specify how the file is to be moved.

summary.para: If a file named lpNewFileName exists, the function replaces its contents with the contents of the lpExistingFileName file.
This value cannot be used if lpNewFileName or lpExistingFileName names a directory.
If the file is to be moved to a different volume, the function simulates the move by using the CopyFile and DeleteFile functions.
If the file is successfully copied to a different volume and the original file is unable to be deleted, the function succeeds leaving the source file intact.
This value cannot be used with .

The system does not move the file until the operating system is restarted. The system moves the file immediately after AUTOCHK is executed, but before creating any paging files. Consequently, this parameter enables the function to delete paging files from previous startups.

This value can only be used if the process is in the context of a user who belongs to the administrators group or the LocalSystem account.
This value cannot be used with .
The function does not return until the file has actually been moved on the disk.
Setting this value guarantees that a move performed as a copy and delete operation is flushed to disk before the function returns. The flush occurs at the end of the copy operation.
This value has no effect if is set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.MoveFileFlags.CreateHardLink
member.summary: Reserved for future use.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.MoveFileFlags.FailIfNotTrackable
member.summary: The function fails if the source file is a link source, but the file cannot be tracked after the move. This situation can occur if the destination is a volume formatted with the FAT file system.

member.summary: Retrieve the display name for the file, which is the name as it appears in Windows Explorer. The name is copied to the member of the structure specified in psfi. The returned display name uses the long file name, if there is one, rather than the 8.3 form of the file name. Note that the display name can be affected by settings such as whether extensions are shown.

member.summary: Retrieve the handle to the icon that represents the file and the index of the icon within the system image list. The handle is copied to the member of the structure specified by psfi, and the index is copied to the member.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.IconLocation
member.summary: Retrieve the name of the file that contains the icon representing the file specified by pszPath, as returned by the method of the file's icon handler. Also retrieve the icon index within that file. The name of the file containing the icon is copied to the member of the structure specified by psfi. The icon's index is copied to that structure's member.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.LargeIcon

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.LinkOverlay

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.OpenIcon
member.summary: Modify , causing the function to retrieve the file's open icon. Also used to modify , causing the function to return the handle to the system image list that contains the file's small open icon. member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions.OverlayIndex

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.Shell.MoveFileWithProgressW(System.String,System.String,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.CopyProgressRoutine,System.IntPtr,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.MoveFileFlags)

summary.para: Moves a file or directory, including its children. You can provide a callback function that receives progress notifications.
To perform this operation as a transacted operation, use the MoveFileTransacted function.

param.name: lpExistingFileName
param.para: The name of the existing file or directory on the local computer.
If specifies , the file cannot exist on a remote share because delayed operations are performed before the network is available.
See Remarks section about the limitation.

param.name: lpNewFileName
param.para: The new name of the file or directory on the local computer.
When moving a file, can be on a different file system or volume. If is on another drive, you must set the flag in .
When moving a directory, and must be on the same drive.

If specifies and is , registers to be deleted when the system restarts. The function fails if it cannot access the registry to store the information about the delete operation. If refers to a directory, the system removes the directory at restart only if the directory is empty.
See Remarks section about the limitation.

member.param: A callback function that is called each time another portion of the file has been moved. The callback function can be useful if you provide a user interface that displays the progress of the operation. This parameter can be .
An argument to be passed to the callback function. This parameter can be .
The move options. This parameter can be one or more of the values of the .

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call .
When moving a file across volumes, if returns (or ) due to the user canceling (or stopping) the operation, will return zero and will return . The existing file is left intact.

remarks.para: The names are limited to characters. To extend this limit to 32,767 wide characters, prepend "\?" to the path. For more information, see Naming a File: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/FileIO/naming-a-file

Tip: Starting with Windows 10, version 1607, you can opt-in to remove the limitation without prepending "\\?\". See the "Maximum Path Length Limitation" section of Naming Files, Paths, and Namespaces for details.
The function coordinates its operation with the link tracking service, so link sources can be tracked as they are moved.

To delete or rename a file, you must have either delete permission on the file or delete child permission in the parent directory. If you set up a directory with all access except delete and delete child and the ACLs of new files are inherited, then you should be able to create a file without being able to delete it. However, you can then create a file, and you will get all the access you request on the handle returned to you at the time you create the file. If you requested delete permission at the time you created the file, you could delete or rename the file with that handle but not with any other.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.Shell.SHGetFileInfo(System.String,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FileAttributes,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.SHFILEINFO@,System.UInt32,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.GetFileInfoOptions)
member.summary: Retrieves information about an object in the file system, such as a file, folder, directory, or drive root.

param.name: pszPath
param.para: A string of maximum length that contains the path and file name. Both absolute and relative paths are valid.

If the parameter includes the flag, this parameter must be the address of an ITEMIDLIST(PIDL) structure that contains the list of item identifiers that uniquely identifies the file within the Shell's namespace. The PIDL must be a fully qualified PIDL. Relative PIDLs are not allowed.

If the parameter includes the flag, this parameter does not have to be a valid file name. The function will proceed as if the file exists with the specified name and with the file attributes passed in the parameter. This allows you to obtain information about a file type by passing just the extension for and passing in .
This string can use either short (the 8.3 form) or long file names.

member.param: A combination of one or more flags. If does not include the flag, this parameter is ignored.
A structure to receive the file information.
The size, in bytes, of the structure pointed to by the parameter.
The flags that specify the file information to retrieve. This parameter can be a combination of the values of the enum.
member.returns:
Returns a value whose meaning depends on the parameter.
If does not contain or , the return value is nonzero if successful, or zero otherwise.
If contains the flag, the return value specifies the type of the executable file. It will be one of the following values. Return code | Description -----------------------------------------------+------------------------------------------ 0 | Nonexecutable file or an error condition. LOWORD = NE or PE and HIWORD = Windows version | Windows application. LOWORD = MZ and HIWORD = 0 | MS-DOS.exe or .com file LOWORD = PE and HIWORD = 0 | Console application or.bat file

remarks.para: You should call this function from a background thread. Failure to do so could cause the UI to stop responding.
If returns an icon handle in the member of the structure pointed to by psfi, you are responsible for freeing it with when you no longer need it.

Note: Once you have a handle to a system image list, you can use the Image List API to manipulate it like any other image list. Because system image lists are created on a per-process basis, you should treat them as read-only objects. Writing to a system image list may overwrite or delete one of the system images, making it unavailable or incorrect for the remainder of the process.

When you use the flag with a Windows application, the Windows version of the executable is given in the HIWORD of the return value. This version is returned as a hexadecimal value. For details on equating this value with a specific Windows version, see Using the Windows Headers.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.CopyProgressRoutine
member.summary: An application-defined callback for some file management. It is called when a portion of a copy or move operation is completed. The LPPROGRESS_ROUTINE type defines a pointer to this callback function. CopyProgressRoutine is a placeholder for the application-defined function name.
member.param: The total size of the file, in bytes.
The total number of bytes transferred from the source file to the destination file since the copy operation began.
The total size of the current file stream, in bytes.
The total number of bytes in the current stream that have been transferred from the source file to the destination file since the copy operation began.
A handle to the current stream. The first time CopyProgressRoutine is called, the stream number is 1.
The reason that was called. This parameter can be one of the values of the enum.
A handle to the source file.
A handle to the destination file.
Argument passed to CopyProgressRoutine by , MoveFileTransacted, or MoveFileWithProgress.
member.returns: The CopyProgressRoutine function should return one of the values of the enum.
member.remarks: An application can use this information to display a progress bar that shows the total number of bytes copied as a percent of the total file size.

member.summary: Resets the window message filter for hWnd to the default. Any message allowed globally or process-wide will get through, but any message not included in those two categories, and which comes from a lower privileged process, will be blocked.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.DesktopWindowManager.MessageFilterAction.Allow

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.DesktopWindowManager.MessageFilterAction.Disallow
member.summary: Blocks the message to be delivered to hWnd if it comes from a lower privileged process, unless the message is allowed process-wide by using the ChangeWindowMessageFilter function or globally.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.DesktopWindowManager.HandlerNativeMethods.GetWindowLongPtr(System.IntPtr,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.DesktopWindowManager.GetWindowLongEnum)
member.summary: Retrieves information about the specified window. The function also retrieves the value at a specified offset into the extra window memory.
member.param: A handle to the window and, indirectly, the class to which the window belongs.

The zero-based offset to the value to be retrieved. Valid values are in the range zero through the number of bytes of extra window memory, minus the size of a LONG_PTR. To retrieve any other value, specify one of the values of the enum.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is the requested value.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call .
If , or has not been called previously, returns zero for values in the extra window or class memory.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.DesktopWindowManager.HandlerNativeMethods.SetWindowLongPtr(System.IntPtr,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.DesktopWindowManager.GetWindowLongEnum,System.Int64)

summary.para: Changes an attribute of the specified window. The function also sets a value at the specified offset in the extra window memory.

This helper static method is required because the 32-bit version of user32.dll does not contain this API (on any versions of Windows), so linking the method will fail at run-time. The bridge dispatches the request to the correct function ( in 32-bit mode and in 64-bit mode).

param.name: hWnd
param.para: A handle to the window and, indirectly, the class to which the window belongs. The function fails if the process that owns the window specified by the hWnd parameter is at a higher process privilege in the UIPI hierarchy than the process the calling thread resides in.
Windows XP/2000: The function fails if the window specified by the hWnd parameter does not belong to the same process as the calling thread.

member.param: The zero-based offset to the value to be set. Valid values are in the range zero through the number of bytes of extra window memory, minus the size of a LONG_PTR. To set any other value, specify one of the values of the .
The replacement value.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is the previous value of the specified offset.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call .

If the previous value is zero and the function succeeds, the return value is zero, but the function does not clear the last error information. To determine success or failure, clear the last error information by calling SetLastError with 0, then call .Function failure will be indicated by a return value of zero and a result that is nonzero.

member.summary: The folder category is not specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderCategory.Virtual
member.summary: The folder is a virtual folder. Virtual folders are not part of the file system. For example, Control Panel and Printers are virtual folders. A number of properties such as folder path and redirection do not apply to this category.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderCategory.Fixed
member.summary: The folder is fixed. Fixed file system folders are not managed by the Shell and are usually given a permanent path when the system is installed. For example, the Windows and Program Files folders are fixed folders. A number of properties such as redirection do not apply to this category.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderCategory.Common
member.summary: The folder is a common folder. Common folders are used for sharing data and settings accessible by all users of a system. For example, all users share a common Documents folder as well as their per-user Documents folder.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.FolderCategory.PerUser
member.summary: Each user has their own copy of the folder. Per-user folders are those stored under each user's profile and accessible only by that user.

member.summary: Registers resources to a Restart Manager session. The Restart Manager uses the list of resources registered with the session to determine which applications and services must be shut down and restarted. Resources can be identified by file names, service short names, or structures that describe running applications.
member.param: A handle to an existing Restart Manager session.
The number of files being registered
An array of null-terminated strings of full filename paths.
The number of processes being registered
An array of structures
The number of services to be registered
An array of null-terminated strings of service short names.

returns.para: The function can return one of the system error codes that are defined in Winerror.h
: Failed to obtain semaphore lock in allotted time.
: An invalid argument was supplied to the function.
: Read/write operation failed.
: Could not allocate memory or instantiate class object.
: No session exists for the supplied handle.

member.summary: Starts a new Restart Manager session. A maximum of 64 Restart Manager sessions per user session can be open on the system at the same time. When this function starts a session, it returns a session handle and session key that can be used in subsequent calls to the Restart Manager API.
member.param: A pointer to the handle of a Restart Manager session.
Reserved. This parameter should be 0.
A null-terminated string that contains the session key to the new session.

returns.para: : Failed to obtain semaphore lock in allotted time.
: An invalid argument was supplied to the function.
: Read/write operation failed.
: Could not allocate memory or instantiate class object.

member.summary: Ends the Restart Manager session. This function should be called by the primary installer that has previously started the session by calling the function. The function can be called by a secondary installer that is joined to the session once no more resources need to be registered by the secondary installer.
member.param: A handle to an existing Restart Manager session.

: Failed to obtain semaphore lock in allotted time.
: An invalid argument was supplied to the function.
: Read/write operation failed.
: Could not allocate memory or instantiate class object.
: No session exists for the supplied handle.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes
member.summary: Describes the event that has occurred. Typically, only one event is specified at a time. If more than one event is specified, the values contained in the dwItem1 and dwItem2 parameters must be the same, respectively, for all specified events. This parameter can be one or more of the following values:

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.None
member.summary: None

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.ItemRename
member.summary: The name of a nonfolder item has changed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the previous PIDL or name of the item. dwItem2 contains the new PIDL or name of the item.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.ItemCreate
member.summary: A nonfolder item has been created. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the item that was created. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.ItemDelete
member.summary: A nonfolder item has been deleted. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the item that was deleted. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DirectoryCreate
member.summary: A folder has been created. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the folder that was created. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DirectoryDelete
member.summary: A folder has been removed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the folder that was removed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.MediaInsert
member.summary: Storage media has been inserted into a drive. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the root of the drive that contains the new media. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.MediaRemove
member.summary: Storage media has been removed from a drive. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the root of the drive from which the media was removed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DriveRemove
member.summary: A drive has been removed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the root of the drive that was removed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DriveAdd
member.summary: A drive has been added. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the root of the drive that was added. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.NetShare
member.summary: A folder on the local computer is being .Shared via the network. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the folder that is being .Shared. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.NetUnshare
member.summary: A folder on the local computer is no longer being .Shared via the network. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the folder that is no longer being .Shared. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.AttributesChange
member.summary: The attributes of an item or folder have changed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the item or folder that has changed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DirectoryContentsUpdate
member.summary: The contents of an existing folder have changed, but the folder still exists and has not been renamed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the folder that has changed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL. If a folder has been created, deleted, or renamed, use SHCNE_MKDIR, SHCNE_RMDIR, or SHCNE_RENAMEFOLDER, respectively.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.Update
member.summary: An existing item (a folder or a nonfolder) has changed, but the item still exists and has not been renamed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the item that has changed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL. If a nonfolder item has been created, deleted, or renamed, use SHCNE_CREATE, SHCNE_DELETE, or SHCNE_RENAMEITEM, respectively, instead.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.ServerDisconnect
member.summary: The computer has disconnected from a server. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the server from which the computer was disconnected. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

members.member: An image in the system image list has changed. SHCNF_DWORD must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 is not used and should be NULL. dwItem2 contains the index in the system image list that has changed. //verify this is not opposite?

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DirectoryRename
member.summary: The name of a folder has changed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the previous PIDL or name of the folder. dwItem2 contains the new PIDL or name of the folder.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.FreeSpace
member.summary: The amount of free space on a drive has changed. SHCNF_IDLIST or SHCNF_PATH must be specified in uFlags. dwItem1 contains the root of the drive on which the free space changed. dwItem2 is not used and should be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.AssociationChange
member.summary: A file type association has changed. SHCNF_IDLIST must be specified in the uFlags parameter. dwItem1 and dwItem2 are not used and must be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.DiskEventsMask
member.summary: Specifies a combination of all of the disk event identifiers.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.GlobalEventsMask
member.summary: Specifies a combination of all of the global event identifiers.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.AllEventsMask
member.summary: All events have occurred.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.ShellObjectChangeTypes.FromInterrupt
member.summary: The specified event occurred as a result of a system interrupt. As this value modifies other event values, it cannot be used alone.

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.DataAccessAndStorage.NativeMethods.FindFirstFile(System.String,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Shell.Win32FindData@)
member.summary: Searches a directory for a file or subdirectory with a name that matches a specific name (or partial name if wildcards are used). See the Remarks section.

param.name: lpFileName
param.para: The directory or path, and the file name. The file name can include wildcard characters, for example, an asterisk (*) or a question mark (?).
This parameter should not be , an invalid string (for example, an empty string or a string that is missing the terminating null character), or end in a trailing backslash (\).
If the string ends with a wildcard, period (.), or directory name, the user must have access permissions to the root and all subdirectories on the path.

In the ANSI version of this function, the name is limited to characters. To extend this limit to 32,767 wide characters, call this Unicode version of the function and prepend "\\?\" to the path. For more information, see Naming a File.

Tip: Starting in Windows 10, version 1607, for the unicode version of this function (), you can opt-in to remove the character limitation without prepending "\\?\". See the "Maximum Path Limitation" section of Naming Files, Paths, and Namespaces for details.

member.param: Information about a found file or directory.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is a search handle used in a subsequent call to or , and the parameter contains information about the first file or directory found.

If the function fails or fails to locate files from the search string in the parameter, the return value is and the contents of are indeterminate. To get extended error information, call the function.
If the function fails because no matching files can be found, the function returns .

remarks.para: To specify additional attributes to use in a search, use the function.
To perform this operation as a transacted operation, use the function.
See FindFirstFileW for other remarks.

summary.para: Name: MFT_SEPARATOR

Description: Specifies that the menu item is a separator. A menu item separator appears as a horizontal dividing line. The dwTypeData and cch members are ignored. This value is valid only in a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu.
Name: MFT_STRING
Description: Displays the menu item using a text string. The member is the pointer to a null-terminated string, and the cch member is the length of the string.
Replaced by: .
Name: MFT_BITMAP
Description: Displays the menu item using a bitmap. The low-order word of the dwTypeData member is the bitmap handle, and the cch member is ignored.
Replaced by: and .
Name: MFT_OWNERDRAW

Description: Assigns responsibility for drawing the menu item to the window that owns the menu. The window receives a message before the menu is displayed for the first time, and a message whenever the appearance of the menu item must be updated. If this value is specified, the dwTypeData member contains an application-defined value.
Name: MFT_MENUBARBREAK

Description: Places the menu item on a new line (for a menu bar) or in a new column (for a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu). For a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu, a vertical line separates the new column from the old.
Name: MFT_MENUBREAK

Description: Places the menu item on a new line (for a menu bar) or in a new column (for a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu). For a drop-down menu, submenu, or shortcut menu, the columns are not separated by a vertical line.
Name: MFT_RIGHTJUSTIFY
Description: Right-justifies the menu item and any subsequent items. This value is valid only if the menu item is in a menu bar.
Name: MFT_RADIOCHECK
Description: Displays selected menu items using a radio-button mark instead of a check mark if the member is .
Name: MFT_RIGHTORDER
Description: Specifies that menus cascade right-to-left (the default is left-to-right). This is used to support right-to-left languages, such as Arabic and Hebrew.
Name: MFS_GRAYED
Description: Disables the menu item and grays it so that it cannot be selected. This is equivalent to .
Name: MFS_DISABLED
Description: Disables the menu item and grays it so that it cannot be selected. This is equivalent to .
Name: MFS_CHECKED
Description: Checks the menu item. For more information about selected menu items, see the member.
Name: MFS_HILITE
Description: Highlights the menu item.
Name: MFS_ENABLED
Description: Enables the menu item so that it can be selected. This is the default state.
Name: MFS_UNCHECKED
Description: Unchecks the menu item. For more information about clear menu items, see the member.
Name: MFS_UNHILITE
Description: Removes the highlight from the menu item. This is the default state.
Name: MFS_DEFAULT
Description: Specifies that the menu item is the default. A menu can contain only one default menu item, which is displayed in bold.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Menus.TrackPopupMenuFlags
member.summary: Options for .

summary.para: Name: TPM_LEFTBUTTON
Description: The user can select menu items with only the left mouse button.
Name: TPM_RIGHTBUTTON
Description: The user can select menu items with both the left and right mouse buttons.
Name: TPM_LEFTALIGN
Description: Positions the shortcut menu so that its left side is aligned with the coordinate specified by the x parameter.
Name: TPM_CENTERALIGN
Description: Centers the shortcut menu horizontally relative to the coordinate specified by the x parameter.
Name: TPM_RIGHTALIGN
Description: Positions the shortcut menu so that its right side is aligned with the coordinate specified by the x parameter.
Name: TPM_TOPALIGN
Description: Positions the shortcut menu so that its top side is aligned with the coordinate specified by the y parameter.
Name: TPM_VCENTERALIGN
Description: Centers the shortcut menu vertically relative to the coordinate specified by the y parameter.
Name: TPM_BOTTOMALIGN
Description: Positions the shortcut menu so that its bottom side is aligned with the coordinate specified by the y parameter.
Name: TPM_HORIZONTAL

Description: If the menu cannot be shown at the specified location without overlapping the excluded rectangle, the system tries to accommodate the requested horizontal alignment before the requested vertical alignment.
Name: TPM_VERTICAL

Description: If the menu cannot be shown at the specified location without overlapping the excluded rectangle, the system tries to accommodate the requested vertical alignment before the requested horizontal alignment.
Name: TPM_NONOTIFY
Description: The function does not send notification messages when the user clicks a menu item.
Name: TPM_RETURNCMD
Description: The function returns the menu item identifier of the user's selection in the return value.
Name: TPM_RECURSE
Description: Displays a menu when another menu is already displayed. This is intended to support context menus within a menu.
Name: TPM_HORPOSANIMATION
Description: Animates the menu from left to right.
Name: TPM_HORNEGANIMATION
Description: Animates the menu from right to left.
Name: TPM_VERPOSANIMATION
Description: Animates the menu from top to bottom.
Name: TPM_VERNEGANIMATION
Description: Animates the menu from bottom to top.
Name: TPM_NOANIMATION
Description: Displays menu without animation.
Name: TPM_LAYOUTRTL
Description: Uses right-to-left text layout. By default, the text layout is left-to-right.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.NamedPipe.Type.Byte
member.summary: Data is written to the pipe as a stream of bytes. This mode cannot be used with . The pipe does not distinguish bytes written during different write operations.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.NamedPipe.Type.Message
member.summary: Data is written to the pipe as a stream of messages. The pipe treats the bytes written during each write operation as a message unit. The function returns when a message is not read completely. This mode can be used with either or .

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.NamedPipe.Access.InBound
member.summary: The flow of data in the pipe goes from client to server only. This mode gives the server the equivalent of GENERIC_READ access to the pipe. The client must specify GENERIC_WRITE access when connecting to the pipe. If the client must read pipe settings by calling the GetNamedPipeInfo or GetNamedPipeHandleState functions, the client must specify GENERIC_WRITE and FILE_READ_ATTRIBUTES access when connecting to the pipe.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.NamedPipe.Access.OutBound
member.summary: The flow of data in the pipe goes from server to client only. This mode gives the server the equivalent of GENERIC_WRITE access to the pipe. The client must specify GENERIC_READ access when connecting to the pipe. If the client must change pipe settings by calling the SetNamedPipeHandleState function, the client must specify GENERIC_READ and FILE_WRITE_ATTRIBUTES access when connecting to the pipe.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.NamedPipe.Access.Duplex
member.summary: The pipe is bi-directional; both server and client processes can read from and write to the pipe. This mode gives the server the equivalent of GENERIC_READ and GENERIC_WRITE access to the pipe. The client can specify GENERIC_READ or GENERIC_WRITE, or both, when it connects to the pipe using the CreateFile function.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.NamedPipe.File.FirstPipeInstance
member.summary: If you attempt to create multiple instances of a pipe with this flag, creation of the first instance succeeds, but creation of the next instance fails with ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.NamedPipe.File.WriteThrough
member.summary: Write-through mode is enabled. This mode affects only write operations on byte-type pipes and, then, only when the client and server processes are on different computers. If this mode is enabled, functions writing to a named pipe do not return until the data written is transmitted across the network and is in the pipe's buffer on the remote computer. If this mode is not enabled, the system enhances the efficiency of network operations by buffering data until a minimum number of bytes accumulate or until a maximum time elapses.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.NamedPipe.File.Overlapped
member.summary: Overlapped mode is enabled. If this mode is enabled, functions performing read, write, and connect operations that may take a significant time to be completed can return immediately. This mode enables the thread that started the operation to perform other operations while the time-consuming operation executes in the background. For example, in overlapped mode, a thread can handle simultaneous input and output (I/O) operations on multiple instances of a pipe or perform simultaneous read and write operations on the same pipe handle. If overlapped mode is not enabled, functions performing read, write, and connect operations on the pipe handle do not return until the operation is finished. The ReadFileEx and WriteFileEx functions can only be used with a pipe handle in overlapped mode. The ReadFile, WriteFile, ConnectNamedPipe, and TransactNamedPipe functions can execute either synchronously or as overlapped operations.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.NamedPipe.NamedPipe
member.summary: Native API for Named Pipes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/remoting/common/RemoteSessionNamedPipe.cs#L124-L256

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.NamedPipe.NamedPipe.CreateNamedPipeW(System.String,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.SecurityAttributes)
member.summary: Creates an instance of a named pipe and returns a handle for subsequent pipe operations. A named pipe server process uses this function either to create the first instance of a specific named pipe and establish its basic attributes or to create a new instance of an existing named pipe.

param.name: lpName
param.para: The unique pipe name. This string must have the following form: \\.\pipe\pipename

The pipename part of the name can include any character other than a backslash, including numbers and special characters. The entire pipe name string can be up to 256 characters long. Pipe names are not case sensitive.

param.name: dwOpenMode
param.para: The open mode.
The function fails if specifies anything other than 0 or the flags listed in the following tables.
This parameter must specify one of the modes. The same mode must be specified for each instance of the pipe.
This parameter can also include one or more of the enum flags, which enable the write-through and overlapped modes. These modes can be different for different instances of the same pipe.
This parameter can include any combination of the security access modes. These modes can be different for different instances of the same pipe.

param.name: dwPipeMode
param.para: The pipe mode.
The function fails if dwPipeMode specifies anything other than 0 or the flags listed in the following tables.
One of the modes can be specified. The same type mode must be specified for each instance of the pipe.
One of the modes can be specified. Different instances of the same pipe can specify different read modes.
One of the modes can be specified. Different instances of the same pipe can specify different wait modes.
One of the modes can be specified. Different instances of the same pipe can specify different remote-client modes.

param.name: nMaxInstances
param.para: The maximum number of instances that can be created for this pipe. The first instance of the pipe can specify this value; the same number must be specified for other instances of the pipe. Acceptable values are in the range 1 through (255).

If this parameter is , the number of pipe instances that can be created is limited only by the availability of system resources. If nMaxInstances is greater than , the return value is INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE and returns .

member.param: The number of bytes to reserve for the output buffer.
The number of bytes to reserve for the input buffer.

param.name: nDefaultTimeOut
param.para: The default time-out value, in milliseconds, if the WaitNamedPipe function specifies NMPWAIT_USE_DEFAULT_WAIT. Each instance of a named pipe must specify the same value.
A value of zero will result in a default time-out of 50 milliseconds.

member.param: A pointer to a structure that specifies a security descriptor for the new named pipe and determines whether child processes can inherit the returned handle. If lpSecurityAttributes is , the named pipe gets a default security descriptor and the handle cannot be inherited. The ACLs in the default security descriptor for a named pipe grant full control to the LocalSystem account, administrators, and the creator owner. They also grant read access to members of the Everyone group and the anonymous account.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is a handle to the server end of a named pipe instance.
If the function fails, the return value is INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE. To get extended error information, call .

member.name: M:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Net.NativeMethods.InternetCloseHandle(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Closes a single Internet handle. See the Remarks section.
member.param: Handle to be closed.
member.returns: Returns if the handle is successfully closed, or otherwise. To get extended error information, call .

remarks.para: The function terminates any pending operations on the handle and discards any outstanding data.

It is safe to call as long as no API calls are being made or will be made using the handle. Once an API has returned , it is safe to call to cancel that I/O, as long as no subsequent API calls will be issued with the handle.

It is safe to call in a callback for the handle being closed. If there is a status callback registered for the handle being closed, and the handle was created with a non- context value, an callback will be made. This indication will be the last callback made from a handle and indicates that the handle is being destroyed.

If asynchronous requests are pending for the handle or any of its child handles, the handle cannot be closed immediately, but it will be invalidated. Any new requests attempted using the handle will return with an notification. The asynchronous requests will complete with . Applications must be prepared to receive any indications on the handle before the final indication is made, which indicates that the handle is completely closed.
An application can call to determine if requests are pending. If returns , there were outstanding requests when the handle was closed.

If returns , as in the case where the function finds no matching files, call the function to retrieve the extended error text, as documented in Handling Errors.

remarks.para: For , file times returned in the structure are in the local time zone, not in a coordinated universal time (UTC) format.

is similar to the function. Note, however, that only one can occur at a time within a given FTP session. The enumerations, therefore, are correlated with the FTP session handle. This is because the FTP protocol allows only a single directory enumeration per session.

After calling and until calling , the application cannot call again on the given FTP session handle. If a call is made to on that handle, the function fails with . After the calling application has finished using the handle returned by , it must be closed using the function.
After beginning a directory enumeration with , the function can be used to continue the enumeration.

Because the FTP protocol provides no standard means of enumerating, some of the common information about files, such as file creation date and time, is not always available or correct. When this happens, and fill in unavailable information with a best guess based on available information. For example, creation and last access dates are often the same as the file's modification date.
The application cannot call between calls to and .

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.StandardClipboardFormats.GDIObjFirst
member.summary: Start of a range of integer values for application-defined GDI object clipboard formats. The end of the range is . Handles associated with clipboard formats in this range are not automatically deleted using the GlobalFree function when the clipboard is emptied. Also, when using values in this range, the hMem parameter is not a handle to a GDI object, but is a handle allocated by the GlobalAlloc function with the GMEM_MOVEABLE flag.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.StandardClipboardFormats.GDIObjLast
member.summary: See .

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.StandardClipboardFormats.HDrop
member.summary: A handle to type HDROP that identifies a list of files. An application can retrieve information about the files by passing the handle to the DragQueryFile function.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.StandardClipboardFormats.Locale
member.summary: The data is a handle to the locale identifier associated with text in the clipboard. When you close the clipboard, if it contains data but no Locale data, the system automatically sets the Locale format to the current input language. You can use the Locale format to associate a different locale with the clipboard text. An application that pastes text from the clipboard can retrieve this format to determine which character set was used to generate the text. Note that the clipboard does not support plain text in multiple character sets. To achieve this, use a formatted text data type such as RTF instead. The system uses the code page associated with Locale to implicitly convert from to . Therefore, the correct code page table is used for the conversion.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.StandardClipboardFormats.MetaFilePicture
member.summary: Handle to a metafile picture format as defined by the MetaFilePicture structure. When passing a MetaFilePicture handle by means of DDE, the application responsible for deleting hMem should also free the metafile referred to by the MetaFilePicture handle.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.StandardClipboardFormats.OEMText
member.summary: Text format containing characters in the OEM character set. Each line ends with a carriage return/linefeed (CR-LF) combination. A null character signals the end of the data.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.StandardClipboardFormats.OwnerDisplay
member.summary: Owner-display format. The clipboard owner must display and update the clipboard viewer window, and receive the WM_ASKCBFORMATNAME, WM_HSCROLLCLIPBOARD, WM_PAINTCLIPBOARD, WM_SIZECLIPBOARD, and WM_VSCROLLCLIPBOARD messages. The hMem parameter must be NULL.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.StandardClipboardFormats.Palette
member.summary: Handle to a color palette. Whenever an application places data in the clipboard that depends on or assumes a color palette, it should place the palette on the clipboard as well. If the clipboard contains data in the Palette (logical color palette) format, the application should use the SelectPalette and RealizePalette functions to realize (compare) any other data in the clipboard against that logical palette. When displaying clipboard data, the clipboard always uses as its current palette any object on the clipboard that is in the Palette format.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.StandardClipboardFormats.PenData
member.summary: Data for the pen extensions to the Microsoft Windows for Pen Computing.

Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP/2000: ES_AWAYMODE_REQUIRED is not supported.

summary.para: The constants are flags that indicate conditions for creating and deleting the object and access modes for the object. The constants are included in the IStorage, System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.IStream, and IPropertySetStorage interfaces and in the StgCreateDocfile, StgCreateStorageEx, StgCreateDocfileOnILockBytes, StgOpenStorage, and StgOpenStorageEx functions.
These elements are often combined using an OR operator. They are interpreted in groups as listed in this class. It is not valid to use more than one element from a single group.
Use a flag from the creation group when creating an object, such as with StgCreateStorageEx or IStorage::CreateStream.
For more information about transactioning, see the Remarks section of the following web page: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/stg/stgm-constants

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.Access.Read
member.summary: Indicates that the object is read-only, meaning that modifications cannot be made. For example, if a stream object is opened with , the System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.ISequentialStream::Read method may be called, but the System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.ISequentialStream::Write method may not. Similarly, if a storage object opened with , the IStorage::OpenStream and IStorage::OpenStorage methods may be called, but the IStorage::CreateStream and IStorage::CreateStorage methods may not.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.Access.Write
member.summary: Enables you to save changes to the object, but does not permit access to its data. The provided implementations of the IPropertyStorage and IPropertySetStorage interfaces do not support this write-only mode.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.Access.ReadWrite
member.summary: Enables access and modification of object data. For example, if a stream object is created or opened in this mode, it is possible to call both System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.IStream::Read and System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.IStream::Write. Be aware that this constant is not a simple binary OR operation of the and elements.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.Sharing.ShareDenyNone
member.summary: Specifies that subsequent openings of the object are not denied read or write access. If no flag from the sharing group is specified, this flag is assumed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.Sharing.ShareDenyRead
member.summary: Prevents others from subsequently opening the object in mode. It is typically used on a root storage object.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.Sharing.ShareDenyWrite
member.summary: Prevents others from subsequently opening the object for or access. In transacted mode, sharing of or can significantly improve performance because they do not require snapshots. For more information about transactioning, see the Remarks section of the web page referenced in the description of the class.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.Sharing.ShareExclusive
member.summary: Prevents others from subsequently opening the object in any mode. Be aware that this value is not a simple bitwise OR operation of the and values. In transacted mode, sharing of or can significantly improve performance because they do not require snapshots. For more information about transactioning, see the Remarks section of the web page referenced in the description of the class.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.Sharing.Priority
member.summary: Opens the storage object with exclusive access to the most recently committed version. Thus, other users cannot commit changes to the object while you have it open in priority mode. You gain performance benefits for copy operations, but you prevent others from committing changes. Limit the time that objects are open in priority mode. You must specify and with priority mode, and you cannot specify . is only valid when creating a root object, such as with StgCreateStorageEx. It is not valid when opening an existing root object, such as with StgOpenStorageEx. It is also not valid when creating or opening a subelement, such as with IStorage::OpenStorage.

summary.para: Indicates that an existing storage object or stream should be removed before the new object replaces it. A new object is created when this flag is specified only if the existing object has been successfully removed.
This flag is used when attempting to create:
- A storage object on a disk, but a file of that name exists.
- An object inside a storage object, but an object with the specified name exists.
- A byte array object, but one with the specified name exists.
This flag cannot be used with open operations, such as StgOpenStorageEx or IStorage::OpenStream.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.Creation.Convert
member.summary: Creates the new object while preserving existing data in a stream named "Contents". In the case of a storage object or a byte array, the old data is formatted into a stream regardless of whether the existing file or byte array currently contains a layered storage object. This flag can only be used when creating a root storage object. It cannot be used within a storage object; for example, in IStorage::CreateStream. It is also not valid to use this flag and the flag simultaneously.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.Creation.FailIfThere
member.summary: Causes the create operation to fail if an existing object with the specified name exists. In this case, STG_E_FILEALREADYEXISTS is returned. This is the default creation mode; that is, if no other create flag is specified, is implied.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.Transactioning.Direct
member.summary: Indicates that, in direct mode, each change to a storage or stream element is written as it occurs. This is the default if neither nor is specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.Transactioning.Transacted
member.summary: Indicates that, in transacted mode, changes are buffered and written only if an explicit commit operation is called. To ignore the changes, call the Revert method in the System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComTypes.IStream, IStorage, or IPropertyStorage interface. The COM compound file implementation of IStorage does not support transacted streams, which means that streams can be opened only in direct mode, and you cannot revert changes to them, however transacted storages are supported. The compound file, stand-alone, and NTFS file system implementations of IPropertySetStorage similarly do not support transacted, simple property sets because these property sets are stored in streams. However, transactioning of nonsimple property sets, which can be created by specifying the PROPSETFLAG_NONSIMPLE flag in the grfFlags parameter of IPropertySetStorage::Create, are supported.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.TransactioningPerformance.NoScratch
member.summary: Indicates that, in transacted mode, a temporary scratch file is usually used to save modifications until the Commit method is called. Specifying permits the unused portion of the original file to be used as work space instead of creating a new file for that purpose. This does not affect the data in the original file, and in certain cases can result in improved performance. It is not valid to specify this flag without also specifying , and this flag may only be used in a root open. For more information about mode, see the Remarks section of the web page referenced in the description of the class.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.TransactioningPerformance.NoSnapshot
member.summary: This flag is used when opening a storage object with and without or . In this case, specifying prevents the system-provided implementation from creating a snapshot copy of the file. Instead, changes to the file are written to the end of the file. Unused space is not reclaimed unless consolidation is performed during the commit, and there is only one current writer on the file. When the file is opened in no snapshot mode, another open operation cannot be performed without specifying . This flag may only be used in a root open operation. For more information about mode, see the Remarks section of the web page referenced in the description of the class.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.DirectSWMRAndSimple.Simple
member.summary: Provides a faster implementation of a compound file in a limited, but frequently used, case. For more information, see the Remarks section of the web page referenced in the description of the class.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.DirectSWMRAndSimple.DirectSWMR
member.summary: Supports direct mode for single-writer, multireader file operations. For more information, see the Remarks section of the web page referenced in the description of the class.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.Storage.STGM.DeleteOnRelease
member.summary: Indicates that the underlying file is to be automatically destroyed when the root storage object is released. This feature is most useful for creating temporary files. This flag can only be used when creating a root object, such as with StgCreateStorageEx. It is not valid when opening a root object, such as with StgOpenStorageEx, or when creating or opening a subelement, such as with IStorage::CreateStream. It is also not valid to use this flag and the flag simultaneously.

member.name: T:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.SecurityAttributes
member.summary: The structure contains the security descriptor for an object and specifies whether the handle retrieved by specifying this structure is inheritable. This structure provides security settings for objects created by various functions, such as CreateFile, CreatePipe, CreateProcess, RegCreateKeyEx, or RegSaveKeyEx.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.SecurityAttributes.nLength
member.summary: The size, in bytes, of this structure. Set this value to the size of the structure.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.SecurityAttributes.lpSecurityDescriptor
member.summary: A class that controls access to the object. If the value of this member is , the object is assigned the default security descriptor associated with the access token of the calling process. This is not the same as granting access to everyone by assigning a discretionary access control list (DACL). By default, the default DACL in the access token of a process allows access only to the user represented by the access token.

member.name: F:Microsoft.WindowsAPICodePack.Win32Native.SecurityAttributes.bInheritHandle
member.summary: A value that specifies whether the returned handle is inherited when a new process is created. If this member is , the new process inherits the handle.
